challenges-to-voters-at-the-polling-plac.name: Challenges to Voters at the Polling Place

subtopics.fact: Appointed challengers and members of the district board
Challenges are permitted at the polls on Election Day.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the restrictions on polling place challenges?

subtopics.fact:
A voter may be challenged on the grounds that they are not qualified to vote. The reasons someone would not be qualified to vote are:  
  
 * They are not a U.S. citizen  
  
 * They are not registered to vote  
  
 * They are not 18 years of age or older  
  
 * They have not been a resident of the county for at least 30 days prior to the election  
  
 * They are a convicted felon on probation or parole.  
  
It is illegal to challenge a voter because: (1) the challenger thinks they know how the voter is going to vote; (2) of the voter's race or ethnic origin; or (3) the voter resides in a particular ward, housing complex, or section of a municipality or county.
subtopics.subtopic: What are the allowed reasons on which a voter can be challenged?

subtopics.fact: A challenger or member of the district board may challenge a voter if they know, suspect or believe the voter not to be qualified or entitled to vote. A challenger must sign an affidavit stating the reason for the challenge.
subtopics.subtopic: Is there a requirement for the challenger to provide cause or evidence?

subtopics.fact: If a voter's right to vote is challenged, the board workers may ask the voter to present identification and the voter must sign an affidavit. The board workers will vote on whether to uphold or reject the challenge. If the challenge is rejected or results in a tie vote, the voter may vote normally. If the board upholds the challenge, the voter may not vote but has the right to go to a Superior Court Judge to request a court order to vote. (The board workers must tell the voter where to find the Judge.)
subtopics.subtopic: How does a voter defend their eligibility to vote if they are challenged?

subtopics.fact: First-time voters who did not register in person with a government official and who did not provide an identifying number on their voter registration application or whose number could not be verified, except for a first-time voter who receives a mail-in (i.e., absentee) ballot because of temporary illness or a temporary or permanent disability or any mail-in military or overseas civilian voter.
subtopics.subtopic: Who must show ID to vote?

citations: Conversation with Gloria Jean Berry, Supervisor of Election Administration, in the New Jersey Secretary of State's office on 7/20/10
subtopics.fact: Identification may include, but is not limited to: (1) any current and valid photo ID, such as a driver's license, student or work ID, military or other government ID, store membership ID, or U.S. passport; or (2) another document such as a bank statement, car registration, government check or document, non-photo driver's license, rent receipt, utility bill, sample ballot (mailed to the voter by the election official) or any other official document.

If a first-time voter who is required to show identification does not show ID, they will only be able to vote by provisional ballot. Then they have until the close of business on the second day after the election to provide identification to the applicable county election office or their ballot will not be counted.
subtopics.subtopic: If a voter has no ID, are there alternatives such as an oath or witness?

subtopics.fact: Yes, as long as it has a photo and is current and valid.
subtopics.subtopic: Is a student ID an acceptable form of identification?

citations: Conversation with the Division of Elections on 8/30/2011.
subtopics.fact: No, but the voter must provide some other documentation to confirm their address (e.g., a utility bill).
subtopics.subtopic: Does the ID have to show the address at which a voter is registered to vote?

citations: Conversation with Gloria Jean Berry, Supervisor of Election Administration, in the New Jersey Secretary of State's office on 7/20/10
subtopics.fact: ID requirements are the same in all elections, regardless of whether a federal candidate is on the ballot.
subtopics.subtopic: Do elections without federal offices on the ballot (such as off-year gubernatorial elections) have different ID requirements?
